metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and apply theoretically and practically the laws of energy and momentum conservation in isolated systems in one dimension

momentum_definition.name: Momentum Definition
momentum_definition.correct: Momentum is the product of mass and velocity. It is a vector quantity with the same direction as velocity. Units are kg m/s or N s.

p = m/v.error: Momentum is mass TIMES velocity, not divided.
p = m/v.fix: p = mv. More mass OR more velocity means more momentum.
p = m/v.action: Check units: kg × m/s = kg m/s. Division would give different units.

p = mv².error: You're confusing momentum with kinetic energy.
p = mv².fix: Momentum: p = mv. Kinetic energy: KE = ½mv².
p = mv².action: Momentum has v, kinetic energy has v². Different quantities.

p = ½mv.error: No factor of ½ in momentum.
p = ½mv.fix: p = mv exactly. The ½ appears in kinetic energy, not momentum.
p = ½mv.action: Momentum: p = mv. KE = ½mv². Don't mix them up.

momentum is a scalar.fix: Momentum has direction (same as velocity). You must specify direction.
momentum is a scalar.action: p = mv. Both v and p have direction. Mass is scalar, but velocity is vector.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the basic definition of momentum.
persistent.action: Memorise: p = mv. Vector quantity. Units: kg m/s or N s. Direction = velocity direction.

momentum_direction.name: Momentum Direction
momentum_direction.formula: Direction of p = direction of v
momentum_direction.correct: Momentum is a vector with the same direction as velocity. Objects moving in opposite directions have momenta with opposite signs.

momentum has no direction.error: Momentum is a vector; it requires direction.
momentum has no direction.fix: The direction of momentum is the same as the direction of velocity.
momentum has no direction.action: If v is to the right, p is to the right. If v is up, p is up.

direction depends on mass.error: Direction depends on velocity, not mass.
direction depends on mass.fix: Mass is always positive. Direction comes from velocity only.
direction depends on mass.action: A 1 kg ball moving left and 100 kg ball moving left both have leftward momentum.

always positive.error: Momentum can be positive or negative depending on direction.
always positive.fix: Choose a sign convention. Moving right = +, moving left = − (or vice versa).
always positive.action: In 1D problems, one direction is + and opposite is −. Be consistent.

perpendicular to velocity.error: Momentum is parallel to velocity, not perpendicular.
perpendicular to velocity.fix: p and v point the same way. p = mv means p is along v.
perpendicular to velocity.action: Draw velocity arrow. Momentum arrow is parallel to it.

persistent.gap: You're not treating momentum as a vector correctly.
persistent.action: Momentum direction = velocity direction. Use sign convention consistently in calculations.

isolated_system.name: Isolated System
isolated_system.formula: No external forces, total momentum constant
isolated_system.correct: An isolated system has no external forces acting on it. Total momentum remains constant in an isolated system.

no forces at all.error: Internal forces exist; there are no EXTERNAL forces.
no forces at all.fix: Objects can exert forces on each other. Just no forces from outside the system.
no forces at all.action: In a collision, objects push each other (internal). No external push needed.

energy cannot enter or leave.error: That's a closed system for energy. Isolated means no external forces.
energy cannot enter or leave.fix: Isolated system: no net external force → momentum conserved.
energy cannot enter or leave.action: In inelastic collisions, energy leaves (as heat/sound), but momentum is still conserved.

objects must be touching.error: The system boundary is conceptual, not physical.
objects must be touching.fix: A system can include objects that interact at a distance.
objects must be touching.action: Two objects about to collide are in the same system before they touch.

only applies to single objects.error: A system includes ALL interacting objects.
only applies to single objects.fix: The system is the collection of objects being studied.
only applies to single objects.action: In a collision, both objects are part of the system.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what makes a system 'isolated'.
persistent.action: Isolated = no net external force. Internal forces can exist. Momentum is conserved.

conservation_of_momentum.name: Conservation of Momentum
conservation_of_momentum.correct: In an isolated system, total momentum before an interaction equals total momentum after. This applies to ALL collisions.

only in elastic collisions.error: Momentum is conserved in ALL collisions, elastic and inelastic.
only in elastic collisions.fix: Momentum: always conserved. Kinetic energy: only in elastic.
only in elastic collisions.action: Key distinction: momentum conserved always; KE conserved only if elastic.

individual momenta stay the same.error: Individual momenta change; only TOTAL momentum is conserved.
individual momenta stay the same.fix: In a collision, p₁ and p₂ change, but p₁ + p₂ stays constant.
individual momenta stay the same.action: Object A loses momentum, Object B gains it. Total unchanged.

p_final = p_initial for each object.error: Conservation applies to the system, not individual objects.
p_final = p_initial for each object.fix: Σp_i = Σp_f means sum of all initial = sum of all final.
p_final = p_initial for each object.action: Total before = Total after. Individual objects can change.

momentum is created in collisions.fix: One object loses what another gains. Total stays constant.
momentum is created in collisions.action: No new momentum appears. It's redistributed between objects.

persistent.gap: You don't understand conservation of momentum.
persistent.action: In isolated system: Σp_before = Σp_after. Always. For ALL collision types.

elastic_collision.name: Elastic Collision
elastic_collision.formula: Both momentum AND kinetic energy conserved
elastic_collision.correct: In elastic collisions, both total momentum AND total kinetic energy are conserved. True elastic collisions are rare; billiard balls are close.

only momentum conserved.error: In elastic, BOTH momentum and KE are conserved.
only momentum conserved.fix: Elastic means no energy lost. Momentum + KE both conserved.
only momentum conserved.action: Elastic collision test: calculate KE before and after. If equal, it's elastic.

objects stick together.error: That's perfectly inelastic. Elastic means they bounce apart.
objects stick together.fix: Elastic: bounce off. Inelastic: stick together or deform.
objects stick together.action: Billiard balls bounce = close to elastic. Cars crumple = inelastic.

no forces during collision.error: Forces definitely act; they're just internal to the system.
no forces during collision.fix: Objects push on each other. That's how momentum transfers.
no forces during collision.action: The forces are equal and opposite (Newton's 3rd law) → momentum conserved.

all collisions are elastic.fix: Truly elastic collisions mainly occur at subatomic level.
all collisions are elastic.action: Real-world: some KE always lost to heat, sound, deformation.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what defines an elastic collision.
persistent.action: Elastic: both momentum AND KE conserved. Objects bounce off. Rare in real world.

inelastic_collision.name: Inelastic Collision
inelastic_collision.correct: In inelastic collisions, momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is NOT conserved. KE is lost to heat, sound, and deformation.

momentum not conserved.error: Momentum is ALWAYS conserved in collisions (isolated system).
momentum not conserved.fix: Inelastic: momentum conserved, KE not conserved.
momentum not conserved.action: Even in car crashes, total momentum is conserved. KE is lost.

kinetic energy increases.error: KE decreases in inelastic collisions, never increases.
kinetic energy increases.fix: Some KE converts to heat, sound, deformation. KE_final < KE_initial.
kinetic energy increases.action: Energy can't appear from nowhere. Inelastic means KE lost, not gained.

objects must bounce off.error: Inelastic includes both sticking together and bouncing with energy loss.
objects must bounce off.fix: Perfectly inelastic: stick together. Inelastic: any KE loss.
objects must bounce off.action: A bouncing ball losing height each bounce is inelastic but doesn't stick.

energy is destroyed.fix: KE → heat, sound, deformation. Total energy is conserved; KE is not.
energy is destroyed.action: The 'lost' KE becomes other forms of energy (heat, sound, etc.).

persistent.action: Inelastic: momentum conserved (always), KE not conserved (decreases). Energy goes to heat/sound/deformation.

kinetic_energy_formula.name: Kinetic Energy Formula
kinetic_energy_formula.correct: Kinetic energy equals half times mass times velocity squared. It is a scalar (no direction) and is always positive.

KE = mv.fix: Momentum: p = mv. Kinetic energy: KE = ½mv².
KE = mv.action: KE has ½ and v². Momentum has neither.

KE = mv².action: The ½ comes from the work-energy derivation. Don't forget it.

KE = ½mv.fix: KE = ½mv². The v² makes it increase rapidly with speed.
KE = ½mv.action: Double the speed → four times the KE (because v is squared).

KE can be negative.error: Kinetic energy is always positive or zero.
KE can be negative.fix: KE = ½mv². Mass is positive, v² is positive, so KE ≥ 0.
KE can be negative.action: Even if velocity is negative, v² is positive. KE has no direction.

persistent.gap: You don't know the kinetic energy formula correctly.
persistent.action: Memorise: KE = ½mv². Scalar, always positive. Compare to p = mv (vector).

ke_vs_momentum.name: KE vs Momentum in Collisions
ke_vs_momentum.formula: Momentum: always conserved. KE: only in elastic
ke_vs_momentum.correct: Momentum is conserved in ALL collisions. Kinetic energy is only conserved in elastic collisions.

both always conserved.error: KE is only conserved in elastic collisions.
both always conserved.action: Test collision type: calculate KE before and after. Equal = elastic.

neither conserved in inelastic.error: Momentum IS conserved even in inelastic collisions.
neither conserved in inelastic.fix: Inelastic: momentum conserved, KE not conserved.
neither conserved in inelastic.action: In any collision, calculate Σp before and after. They're equal.

KE always conserved, momentum varies.fix: Momentum is ALWAYS conserved. KE conservation depends on collision type.

same rules for both.fix: Momentum: conserved in all collisions. KE: conserved only in elastic.
same rules for both.action: Make a table: Elastic (p: yes, KE: yes), Inelastic (p: yes, KE: no).

persistent.gap: You're confusing momentum and KE conservation rules.
persistent.action: Momentum: always conserved (in isolated system). KE: only conserved in elastic collisions.

energy_dissipation.name: Energy Dissipation
energy_dissipation.correct: In inelastic collisions, the 'lost' kinetic energy is transformed into heat, sound, and permanent deformation of objects.

energy disappears.error: Energy is conserved; it transforms, not disappears.
energy disappears.fix: KE becomes heat, sound, deformation. Total energy is conserved.
energy disappears.action: After a crash: feel the warm metal, hear the sound. That's where KE went.

energy is created.error: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.
energy is created.fix: Energy transforms from one form to another.
energy is created.action: Law of conservation of energy: total energy constant, forms change.

only heat is produced.error: Heat, sound, AND deformation all absorb energy.
only heat is produced.fix: KE → heat + sound + deformation (crumpling, breaking, etc.).
only heat is produced.action: In a car crash: hot metal, loud bang, crumpled body. All absorb KE.

dissipated energy can be recovered.error: Dissipated energy is 'degraded' and hard to recover.
dissipated energy can be recovered.fix: Heat, sound spread out and can't easily be converted back to KE.
dissipated energy can be recovered.action: This is why perpetual motion machines don't work.

persistent.gap: You don't understand where 'lost' kinetic energy goes.
persistent.action: In inelastic collisions: KE → heat + sound + deformation. Energy transforms, not disappears.

perfectly_inelastic.name: Perfectly Inelastic Collision
perfectly_inelastic.formula: Objects stick together, maximum KE loss
perfectly_inelastic.correct: In perfectly inelastic collisions, objects stick together and move as one. This results in maximum kinetic energy loss while still conserving momentum.

no momentum conservation.error: Momentum is still conserved even when objects stick.
no momentum conservation.action: Combined mass moves with common final velocity. Momentum conserved.

all KE is lost.error: Not all KE is lost unless they come to rest.
all KE is lost.fix: If combined object still moves, it has KE. Just less than before.
all KE is lost.action: Only if initial momenta exactly cancel do they stop (KE = 0).

objects bounce apart.error: Perfectly inelastic means they stick together.
objects bounce apart.fix: Stick together = perfectly inelastic. Bounce = elastic or partially inelastic.
objects bounce apart.action: Coupling train cars, catching a ball—these are perfectly inelastic.

same as elastic.error: Perfectly inelastic is the opposite extreme from elastic.
same as elastic.fix: Elastic: bounce, KE conserved. Perfectly inelastic: stick, maximum KE lost.
same as elastic.action: Spectrum: elastic (KE same) → inelastic → perfectly inelastic (max KE loss).

persistent.gap: You don't understand perfectly inelastic collisions.
persistent.action: Perfectly inelastic: objects stick together, move as one, maximum KE loss, momentum still conserved.

collision_calculations.name: Collision Calculation Strategy
collision_calculations.formula: Use Σp_i = Σp_f, then check KE
collision_calculations.correct: To solve collision problems: (1) Calculate total initial momentum, (2) Apply conservation to find final velocities, (3) Compare KE before and after to classify collision type.

only use KE conservation.error: Start with momentum conservation; it always applies.
only use KE conservation.fix: Momentum first (always conserved), then check if KE is also conserved.
only use KE conservation.action: Step 1: Σp_i = Σp_f. Step 2: Calculate KE_i and KE_f. Step 3: Compare.

assume elastic.error: Don't assume collision type; calculate and check.
assume elastic.fix: Calculate KE before and after. Equal = elastic. Different = inelastic.
assume elastic.action: Many exam questions ask you to determine if elastic or inelastic.

ignore direction.error: Direction matters because momentum is a vector.
ignore direction.fix: Assign positive direction. Opposite motion = negative velocity.
ignore direction.action: If objects move opposite ways, one has + velocity, one has −.

final KE = initial KE always.fix: Check: KE_f = KE_i? If yes, elastic. If no, inelastic.
final KE = initial KE always.action: Calculate both. Don't assume they're equal.

persistent.gap: You're not following the correct collision problem strategy.
persistent.action: Strategy: (1) Use Σp_i = Σp_f to find velocities, (2) Calculate KE_i and KE_f, (3) Compare to determine collision type.

energy_conservation_total.name: Total Energy Conservation
energy_conservation_total.correct: Total energy (all forms) is always conserved, even in inelastic collisions. Only kinetic energy specifically may not be conserved.

energy is lost in inelastic.error: KE is lost, but total energy is conserved.
energy is lost in inelastic.fix: KE transforms to other forms (heat, sound). Total energy unchanged.
energy is lost in inelastic.action: Distinguish: KE not conserved ≠ total energy not conserved.

conservation only in elastic.error: Total energy is ALWAYS conserved. KE only in elastic.
conservation only in elastic.fix: Total energy: always conserved. Kinetic energy: only in elastic.
conservation only in elastic.action: In inelastic: KE → heat + sound + deformation. Still adds up to same total.

momentum and energy are the same.error: They're different quantities with different conservation rules.
momentum and energy are the same.fix: Momentum: vector, always conserved in collisions. Energy: scalar, total always conserved.
momentum and energy are the same.action: p = mv (vector). KE = ½mv² (scalar). Different formulas, different rules.

energy can be created in collisions.error: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.
energy can be created in collisions.fix: Law of conservation of energy: total energy constant in isolated system.
energy can be created in collisions.action: Energy transforms between forms but total never changes.

persistent.gap: You're confusing KE conservation with total energy conservation.
persistent.action: Total energy: always conserved. KE specifically: only in elastic collisions. KE can transform to heat/sound.

momentum_basics.title: Understanding Momentum
momentum_basics.instructions: Complete the statements about the basics of momentum.

sentences.text: Momentum is calculated using the formula p = {{d1}}. It is a {{d2}} quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction.
The SI unit for momentum is {{d3}}, which is equivalent to {{d4}}. The direction of momentum is the same as the direction of {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: Mass times velocity gives what units?

d4.tooltip: Newton-second is another way to express momentum units.

d5.tooltip: Which quantity in p = mv gives direction?

sentences.text: A 2 kg object moving at 5 m/s to the right has momentum {{d6}} kg m/s. If it reversed direction at the same speed, its momentum would be {{d7}} kg m/s.

momentum_conservation.title: Conservation of Momentum
momentum_conservation.instructions: Complete the statements about momentum conservation.

sentences.text: An isolated system is one where there are no {{d1}} forces acting. In such a system, the total momentum is {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What type of forces must be absent?

d2.tooltip: What happens to momentum in an isolated system?

sentences.text: The law of conservation of momentum states that in an isolated system, {{d3}} equals {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What is conserved? The sum of all momenta.

d4.tooltip: The total before equals the total after.

sentences.text: Momentum is conserved in {{d5}} collisions. This includes both elastic and inelastic collisions, as long as the system is {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Does collision type affect momentum conservation?

d6.tooltip: What condition is needed for conservation?

elastic_inelastic.title: Elastic and Inelastic Collisions
elastic_inelastic.instructions: Complete the statements about collision types.

sentences.text: In an elastic collision, both momentum and {{d1}} are conserved. In an inelastic collision, momentum is conserved but {{d2}} is not.

d1.tooltip: What else is conserved in elastic collisions?

d2.tooltip: What is NOT conserved in inelastic?

sentences.text: Kinetic energy is calculated using KE = {{d3}}. Unlike momentum, kinetic energy is a {{d4}} quantity.

d3.tooltip: The formula has ½ and velocity squared.

sentences.text: True elastic collisions are {{d5}} in everyday life. Collisions between billiard balls are {{d6}} elastic.

d5.tooltip: How often do we see perfect elastic collisions?

d6.tooltip: Billiard balls are close but not perfect.

energy_conservation.title: Energy Conservation in Collisions
energy_conservation.instructions: Complete the statements about energy in collisions.

sentences.text: In inelastic collisions, the kinetic energy that is 'lost' is actually transformed into {{d1}}, {{d2}}, and permanent deformation of objects.
The total energy in a collision is {{d3}} conserved, even in inelastic collisions. Only {{d4}} energy may not be conserved.

d3.tooltip: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.

d4.tooltip: Which type of energy is specifically not conserved in inelastic?

sentences.text: In a perfectly inelastic collision, objects {{d5}} after collision. This results in the {{d6}} amount of kinetic energy being lost.

d5.tooltip: What happens to objects in perfectly inelastic collision?

d6.tooltip: Perfectly inelastic has the most KE loss.

sentences.text: A 1500 kg car travelling at 20 m/s has momentum p = {{d1}} kg m/s. A 3000 kg truck travelling at 10 m/s has momentum p = {{d2}} kg m/s. They have {{d3}} momentum.
If an object's mass doubles while velocity stays constant, momentum {{d4}}. If velocity doubles while mass stays constant, momentum {{d5}} but kinetic energy {{d6}}.

momentum_conservation.title: Applying Momentum Conservation
momentum_conservation.instructions: Apply conservation of momentum to collisions.

sentences.text: A 5 kg ball moving at 4 m/s collides with a stationary 3 kg ball. Total initial momentum = {{d1}} kg m/s. After collision, total momentum must {{d2}} this value.
Two objects with equal mass collide head-on at equal speeds. The total initial momentum is {{d3}}. If they stick together, their final velocity is {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Equal and opposite momenta cancel: p + (−p) = 0.

d4.tooltip: If total p = 0 before, total p = 0 after.

sentences.text: In a cannon recoil, the cannonball gains momentum forward. For momentum to be conserved, the cannon must gain {{d5}} momentum. This is an example of {{d6}} forces.

elastic_inelastic.title: Classifying Collisions
elastic_inelastic.instructions: Determine collision types based on energy analysis.

sentences.text: Two 2 kg balls collide. Before: total KE = 100 J. After: total KE = 100 J. This collision is {{d1}}. Momentum {{d2}} conserved.

d1.tooltip: KE before = KE after means elastic.

d2.tooltip: Momentum is ALWAYS conserved in collisions.

sentences.text: A car crash: KE before = 500 kJ, KE after = 50 kJ. The collision is {{d3}}. The 450 kJ difference went into {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Where does the lost KE go?

sentences.text: To determine if a collision is elastic, compare {{d5}} before and after. If they're equal, it's elastic. Momentum comparison {{d6}} tell you the collision type.

d5.tooltip: What quantity distinguishes elastic from inelastic?

d6.tooltip: Momentum is conserved in ALL collisions.

sentences.text: A 3 kg object at 4 m/s collides and sticks to a 1 kg stationary object. Initial KE = ½(3)(4²) = {{d1}} J. Final velocity = {{d2}} m/s.
Continuing: Final KE = ½(4)(3²) = {{d3}} J. Energy lost = {{d4}} J. Since KE decreased, this confirms the collision is {{d5}}.

The key difference between momentum and kinetic energy is that momentum is a {{d1}} while kinetic energy is a {{d2}}. This means objects moving in opposite directions have momenta that can {{d3}}, but their kinetic energies always {{d4}}.
A common misconception is that heavier objects always have more momentum. In fact, a 1 kg bullet at 500 m/s has {{d5}} momentum than a 1000 kg car at 0.4 m/s because momentum depends on {{d6}}.
The law of conservation of momentum follows from {{d1}}. If two objects exert equal and opposite forces on each other for the same time, they experience equal and opposite changes in {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Action-reaction pairs lead to momentum conservation.

sentences.text: In explosions where an object breaks apart, momentum is {{d3}} conserved because the forces are {{d4}}. If a stationary bomb explodes, the fragments have momenta that sum to {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: Internal forces don't change total momentum.

elastic_inelastic.title: Mastering Collision Analysis
elastic_inelastic.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of collision types.

sentences.text: The spectrum of collisions ranges from {{d1}} (objects bounce with no KE loss) to {{d2}} (objects stick together with maximum KE loss). Most real collisions fall somewhere {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: Most collisions lose some but not all KE.

sentences.text: In a head-on collision between identical masses at equal speeds, if perfectly inelastic, final KE = {{d4}}. This represents the {{d5}} possible energy loss while still conserving momentum.

d4.tooltip: Equal opposite momenta cancel → v_f = 0 → KE = 0.

d5.tooltip: All KE converted to other forms.

sentences.text: To verify a collision is elastic: Step 1: Calculate {{d6}}. Step 2: Calculate {{d7}}. Step 3: Compare—if equal, elastic; if different, inelastic.

energy_conservation.title: Mastering Energy Conservation
energy_conservation.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of energy in collisions.

sentences.text: The distinction between 'energy conservation' and 'kinetic energy conservation' is crucial. Total energy is {{d1}} conserved. Kinetic energy is only conserved in {{d2}} collisions.

d2.tooltip: KE is conserved only in elastic collisions.

sentences.text: In real-world safety design (crumple zones, airbags), we {{d3}} want elastic collisions because energy dissipation through {{d4}} reduces the forces on occupants.

d3.tooltip: We want energy absorbed, not bounced back.

d4.tooltip: Crumple zones absorb energy by deforming.

sentences.text: Summary: In isolated systems, {{d5}} is always conserved in collisions. {{d6}} is only conserved in elastic collisions. When KE is not conserved, it transforms into {{d7}}.

d7.tooltip: The 'lost' KE becomes other energy forms.
